results.title: [George Malins Home Movies: Reel 20]
results.brief_description:
George William Malins (1910–2007) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to 1970s. According to his daughter, George was ‘optimistic, happy and enthusiastic’, an outlook reflected in his films which are a history of home life and a love of travel.

George came to Australia from England as a young man by way of the merchant navy, after having seen South America and some of Asia. He met his future wife Sybil, who was impressed by George’s world travels and his dreams for the future.

The family lived in the Melbourne suburb of North Balwyn, spending their summers camping at Wye River on the Victorian coast often with extended family and friends.

George and Sybil must have shared a sense of adventure as they eventually sold the family home and sailed on the ‘SS Orontes’ to England, travelling around Britain for two years.

The George Malins Home Movie Collection was donated to ACMI by the creator’s daughter, Ruth Hargrave. The films were made on 16mm film.

This film contains two distinct scenes most likely taken at different times - firstly we see an infant girl in a garden and secondly members of the extended family at the beach.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 an infant girl walking about a garden in a yellow dress with smocking detail on the front yoke, very much the style of the day
00:00:15:00 title card written in the sand ‘Sue & John’ immediately washed away by a wave before reappearing as ‘Sue & John Just Friends’
00:00:44:00 a glimpse of guests sipping from champagne glasses at a celebration or wedding
00:00:49:00 two people we can presume are Sue and John and two friends
00:01:14:00 Sue walks toward the camera with 1960s style cars behind her
00:01:23:00 titles ‘The End’ and ‘Sue John Just Friends’ in the sand
00:01:34:00 title ‘Mr and Mrs Malins’ and a 1960s style wedding card
00:01:42:00 sign for ‘The Sanctuary’ hangs outside a building followed by titles ‘Two Years Later’, the church sign for ‘St Judes Randwick’ and ‘The End’ in quick succession.

results.title: [George Malins Home Movies: Reel 19]
results.brief_description:
George William Malins (1910–2007) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to 1970s. According to his daughter, George was ‘optimistic, happy and enthusiastic’, an outlook reflected in his films which are a history of home life and a love of travel.

George came to Australia from England as a young man by way of the merchant navy, after having seen South America and some of Asia. He met his future wife Sybil, who was impressed by George’s world travels and his dreams for the future.

The family lived in the Melbourne suburb of North Balwyn, spending their summers camping at Wye River on the Victorian coast often with extended family and friends.

George and Sybil must have shared a sense of adventure as they eventually sold the family home and sailed on the ‘SS Orontes’ to England, travelling around Britain for two years.

The George Malins Home Movie Collection was donated to ACMI by the creator’s daughter, Ruth Hargrave. The films were made using 16mm film.

This film shows some of the family travels through Europe in their Bedford camper van. We see the ferry crossing between Malmo, Sweden and Copenhagen, Denmark, a campground and a border check point.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 we see the ferry between Malmo, Sweden and Copenhagen, Denmark crossing the water; there is a large DFDS Seaways (a Danish shipping company) cruiser behind
00:00:24:00 a flock of seagulls flying over the deck of the boat
00:00:43:00 a campground, featuring colourful tents and the Malins’s camping set up
00:01:14:00 the Bedford van arrives at a checkpoint, pulling up beside a yellow Volkswagen Kombi van; there is a sign reading ‘Report here’ in multiple languages: Dutch, French, German and Swedish
00:01:37:00 the van drives onto a ferry with Union Jack flag painted onto the side
00:01:45:00 city streets in what appears to be London

results.title: [George Malins Home Movies: Reel 18]
results.brief_description:
George William Malins (1910–2007) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to 1970s. According to his daughter, George was ‘optimistic, happy and enthusiastic’, an outlook reflected in his films which are a history of home life and a love of travel.

George came to Australia from England as a young man by way of the merchant navy, after having seen South America and some of Asia. He met his future wife Sybil, who was impressed by George’s world travels and his dreams for the future.

The family lived in the Melbourne suburb of North Balwyn, spending their summers camping at Wye River on the Victorian coast often with extended family and friends.

George and Sybil must have shared a sense of adventure as they eventually sold the family home and sailed on the ‘SS Orontes’ to England, travelling around Britain for two years.

The George Malins Home Movie Collection was donated to ACMI by the creator’s daughter, Ruth Hargrave. The films were made on 16mm film.

This film shows a collection of scenes including a QANTAS plane leaving the airport, a group of family and friends in the backyard of a suburban home, dressed for a celebration, and the Malinses’s Bedford camper van.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 a group of kangaroos in grassy parkland
00:00:12:00 close-up of kangaroo with joey in her pouch
00:00:48:00 QANTAS airplane on the tarmac of Melbourne Airport, departing
00:01:21:00 a group of people on the lawn in a garden dressed in 1970s style clothing at what seems to be a celebration - great examples of 70s patterns and dress styles
00:01:55:00 close-up of man in white pants and pink check shirt with a pink ribbon flower attached to his back pocket digging in the garden bed; purple hydrangeas at the back of the bed and wishbone ferns at the front
00:02:10:00 exterior of a suburban brick house with venetian blinds and pot plants
00:02:19:00 a man drives a two-toned green Morris van out of the driveway
00:02:35:00 George and Sybil Malins with their Bedford camper van in a campground

results.title: [George Malins Home Movies: Reel 17]
results.brief_description:
George William Malins (1910–2007) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to 1970s. According to his daughter, George was ‘optimistic, happy and enthusiastic’, an outlook reflected in his films which are a history of home life and a love of travel.

George came to Australia from England as a young man by way of the merchant navy, after having seen South America and some of Asia. He met his future wife Sybil, who was impressed by George’s world travels and his dreams for the future.

The family lived in the Melbourne suburb of North Balwyn, spending their summers camping at Wye River on the Victorian coast often with extended family and friends.

George and Sybil must have shared a sense of adventure as they eventually sold the family home and sailed on the ‘SS Orontes’ to England, travelling around Britain for two years.

The George Malins Home Movie Collection was donated to ACMI by the creator’s daughter, Ruth Hargrave. The films were made on 16mm film.

This film shows a family picnic in a parkland or bush, featuring a 1950s style car. The family pose for the camera, smile and wave. The film is a good example of picnicking and fashion of the period.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 a family picnic beside a 1950s style car in a bush or parkland setting
00:00:26:00 great shot of a young boy grimacing with effort as he pops open a bottle with a utensil
00:00:39:00 close-up of a woman holding a baby
00:01:07:00 a man and woman hug surrounded by trees
00:01:13:00 the family exit the car in the driveway of a brick house, waving and smiling at the camera; the house features a large striped awning over the window

results.title: [George Malins Home Movies: Reel 16]
results.brief_description:
George William Malins (1910–2007) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to 1970s. According to his daughter, George was ‘optimistic, happy and enthusiastic’, an outlook reflected in his films which are a history of home life and a love of travel.

George came to Australia from England as a young man by way of the merchant navy, after having seen South America and some of Asia. He met his future wife Sybil, who was impressed by George’s world travels and his dreams for the future.

The family lived in the Melbourne suburb of North Balwyn, spending their summers camping at Wye River on the Victorian coast often with extended family and friends.

George and Sybil must have shared a sense of adventure as they eventually sold the family home and sailed on the ‘SS Orontes’ to England, travelling around Britain for two years.

The George Malins Home Movie Collection was donated to ACMI by the creator’s daughter, Ruth Hargrave. The films were made on 16mm film.

A short film of a road trip to Albany, Western Australia, including a visit to the whale processing station, in operation at the time of the film. The Cheynes Beach Whaling Station, located at Frenchman Bay in King George Sound, east of Albany, operated from 1952 to 1978 and was the last operating whaling station in Australia.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 kangaroo in open bushland with gumtrees in the background, filmed at dusk or dawn
00:00:18:00 men working on the whale processing station, cutting large pieces of a whale carcass and hosing down the deck
00:01:06:00 a signpost pointing to ‘Albany (21)’ in one direction and ‘Whaling Station (1)’ in the other, with the coastline in the background
00:01:15:00 view from inside the front windscreen of a vehicle driving along the road, leaving Western Australia; a sign gradually appears reading ‘State Border, Come Again to Western Australia’
00:01:36:00 what appears to be a 1950s model Bedford camper van driving down the road through swirls of dust

00:01:15:00 view from inside the front windscreen of a vehicle driving along the road, leaving Western Australia; a sign gradually appears reading ‘State Border, Come Again to Western Australia’
00:01:36:00 what appears to be a 1950s model Bedford camper van driving down the road through swirls of dust

results.title: [George Malins Home Movies: Reel 15]
results.brief_description:
George William Malins (1910–2007) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to 1970s. According to his daughter, George was ‘optimistic, happy and enthusiastic’, an outlook reflected in his films which are a history of home life and a love of travel.

George came to Australia from England as a young man by way of the merchant navy, after having seen South America and some of Asia. He met his future wife Sybil, who was impressed by George’s world travels and his dreams for the future.

The family lived in the Melbourne suburb of North Balwyn, spending their summers camping at Wye River on the Victorian coast often with extended family and friends.

George and Sybil must have shared a sense of adventure as they eventually sold the family home and sailed on the ‘SS Orontes’ to England, travelling around Britain for two years.

The George Malins Home Movie Collection was donated to ACMI by the creator’s daughter, Ruth Hargrave. The films were made on 16mm film.

This film takes place during a trip to Port Moresby in Papua New Guinea. The film shows members of the Royal Papua Yacht Club sailing on the harbour, from the perspective of another yacht.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 view of building painted with sign ‘Royal Papua Yacht Club’
00:00:11:00 yachts sailing on the water, including close ups of rigging and sails and what appears to be a bamboo mast
00:00:39:00 group of men on a yellow sailing yacht, filmed from yacht alongside
00:00:52:00 yachts sailing on the harbour from different vantage points: in some shots open sea can be seen in the background; in others the cliffs of the harbour and the buildings of the city of Port Moresby
00:01:35:00 we see a man seated on the deck of the boat, smiling at the camera while adjusting ropes in the wind
00:02:16:00 a second man in a short sleeve shirt releasing a large floating buoy onto the water over the side of the boat; the buoy is decorated with the classic shield logo of BP (formerly British Petroleum), with yellow initials on a green shield design
00:02:32:00 the man is now seated on the edge of the boat while a third man cleans a firearm

results.title: [George Malins Home Movies: Reel 14]
results.brief_description:
George William Malins (1910–2007) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to 1970s. According to his daughter, George was ‘optimistic, happy and enthusiastic’, an outlook reflected in his films which are a history of home life and a love of travel.

George came to Australia from England as a young man by way of the merchant navy, after having seen South America and some of Asia. He met his future wife Sybil, who was impressed by George’s world travels and his dreams for the future.

The family lived in the Melbourne suburb of North Balwyn, spending their summers camping at Wye River on the Victorian coast often with extended family and friends.

George and Sybil must have shared a sense of adventure as they eventually sold the family home and sailed on the ‘SS Orontes’ to England, travelling around Britain for two years.

The George Malins Home Movie Collection was donated to ACMI by the creator’s daughter, Ruth Hargrave. The films were made on 16mm film.

This film contains snippets of scenes from travels around Victoria. Firstly the Hume Dam (formerly Hume Weir) which is a major dam across the Murray River in New South Wales. Constructed between 1919 and 1936 and involving hydro-power as well as flood mitigation and irrigation, the Hume Dam would have been a major attraction at the time, the 1940s. There are also some scenes of the family children during what seems to be a stop along the way.

This very short black and white film is faded throughout.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:24:00 a man in suit and hat clambering over large boulders and looking out at a view
00:00:45:00 the spillway drains at the Hume Dam
00:01:05:00 children smiling at the camera while standing near a car
00:01:17:00 one of the children holds what might be a small rabbit or possum

results.title: [Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movie Collection]
results.brief_description:
Tibor Zoltan Koller (1920-1975) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to the early 1970s. Born in Budapest, Hungary, Tibor lived in Melbourne, Victoria with his family. Wife Merna Koller was a frequent collaborator on these films, showing a shared interest in filmmaking.

Tibor captured suburban family life in Melbourne, including family celebrations, urban scenes and regional holidays. Tibor was actively engaged in the lapidary society of Australia. Several of his films show opal fields and gemstone artisans at work, as well as the 1969 ‘Gemboree’ in Beechworth, Victoria, a national festival organised by the lapidary clubs of Australia. Tibor also travelled to Idar-Oberstein in Germany, historically known as a gemstone town, and to Japan.

The Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s daughter Vicki Koller. The films were made on Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

results.title: [Len Moncur Home Movie Collection]
results.brief_description:
The Len Moncur Home Movie Collection is a collection of amateur films made on 8mm film in the 1950s and 1960s. The collection includes a feature-length film of the 1956 Melbourne Olympics and four stop-motion animation titles: ‘The one-eyed monster’, ‘Storm at the 20th’, ‘One fine day’ and ‘It isn’t cricket’.

Len Moncur (1912–1997) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies and amimation films. With an interest in radio from a young age, he obtained his amateur transmitting licence in 1928, and served in the Air Force during WWII in radar service units. He purchased his first film camera in the USA in 1935, while on a trip visiting other radio and television experimenters, and began making home movies. He made an amaetur television set in 1950, which was shown at the All Models Exhibition, six years before the arrival of commerical television in Australia. In 1957, he joined the Melbourne 8mm Movie Club, where he regularly screened his home movies at film nights. Moncur’s 8mm stop-motion animation films won several amateur filmmaking awards in the 1960s.

This collection was donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s son Ken Moncur.

results.title: [Len Moncur Home Movies: Reel 5]
results.brief_description:
The Len Moncur Home Movie Collection is a collection of amateur films made on 8mm film in the 1950s and 1960s.

This animated film, titled ‘Storm at the 20th’, is a comedy about a group of beleaguered golf ball people, often wearing golf tee hats and with pipe cleaner limbs, who come together to protest against injury from golfers. They decide to take evasive action including using feathers to fly out of the way of golf sticks and a self-destructing do-it-yourself glider kit.

There are details such as the terrible injuries inflicted by golfers and one of the organisers drinking non-stop from what looks like a whiskey bottle.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:07:00 title cards ‘Storm at the 20th’ and ‘Animation by Len Moncur’
00:00:10:00 golf ball people are rushing around a busy street
00:00:18:00 a sign ‘Protest Meeting - Every Brand - Even repaints – Something must be done!’
00:00:26:00 sign ‘Trades Hall 20th Hole Branch’
00:00:29:00 wonderful miniature and detailed vehicles pass by including a tram from which many golf ball people alight
00:00:38:00 close-up of ‘Before it happens towing service’ tow truck
00:00:43:00 golf ball mechanics fix a broken down vehicle
00:00:50:00 an injured golf ball mechanic is taken away by stretcher and ambulance
00:01:16:00 the protest meeting proceeds with the manifesto stating that golf ball people are being treated badly by golfers
00:01:25:00 one of the organisers drinking strong spirits followed by several examples of gruesome golf ball injuries
00:02:35:00 baby golf ball people in a bassinette
00:02:48:00 the golf ball people learn evasive tactics on the golf course
00:04:33:00 boxes labelled ‘Do it yourself Glider Kit’ followed by a demonstration of how the glider assists the golf ball person avoid being hit by a golfer by flying through the air and then self-destructing once the golf ball person shields in a bush
00:05:09:00 the golf ball people squash into their sporty car and after travelling down the road, pop themselves into their boxes
00:05:24:00 title ‘The End’
